THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

  
    
      
        Steven Roy
          Earley, Petitioner,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Lexington County
Mark H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge
Â Clyde N. Davis, Jr., Post-Conviction
Relief Judge

Memorandum Opinion No. 2008-MO-041
  Submitted September 18, 2008 â€“ Filed
October 27, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, South Carolina Commission on Indigent
          Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
          Attorney General Daniel E. Grigg, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Steven Roy Earley
  pled guilty in 2003 to a charge of murder.Â  The plea judge sentenced Earley to
  thirty years in prison pursuant to a plea agreement.Â  Earley did not file a
  direct appeal.Â  He subsequently filed a PCR application alleging ineffective
  assistance of counsel.Â  Among other things, Earley asserted counsel failed to
  file an appeal.Â  The PCR judge denied the application, finding counsel was not
  ineffective.Â  This Court granted Earleyâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari and
  granted him a belated appeal pursuant to White v. State, 263 S.C. 110,
  208 S.E.2d 35 (1974).Â  
Earley has now
  filed a brief for his belated appeal in which he argues that his guilty plea
  was not knowingly and voluntarily entered as required by Boykin v. Alabama,
  395 U.S. 238 (1969).Â  Specifically, Earley contends (1) he was not advised
  that if he were tried by a jury the verdict would have to be unanimous, and (2)
  the plea in this case was supported by only two pages of facts.
We
  affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  State
    v. McKinney, 278 S.C. 107, 292 S.E.2d 598 (1982) (holding the unknowing and
  involuntary nature of a guilty plea cannot be attacked on direct appeal absent
  a timely objection on this basis at the plea proceeding); McCray v. State,
  271 S.C. 185, 188, 246 S.E.2d 230, 231 (1978) (stating, in the context of a
  belated appeal under White, a â€œdefendant can . . . raise and argue on
  the â€˜belated appealâ€™ [only] those issues [that] could have been raised and
  argued on a timely direct appealâ€); State v. Lambert, 266 S.C. 574, 579,
  225 S.E.2d 340, 342 (1976) (holding a plea judge need not â€œdirect the
  defendantâ€™s attention to each and every constitutional right and obtain a
  separate waiver of eachâ€ and that â€œan enumeration of specific rights waived is
  not required where the record otherwise reveals affirmative awareness of the
  consequences of a guilty pleaâ€).
AFFIRMED.
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.
